I remember just running out to my car, grabbing my military uniform, which was in the trunk of my car in a (unintelligible).
I see three unmarked cars just fly by me and they were just headed in the direction of Ground Zero.
So I said let me attach myself to this convoy, because they're going in my direction.
And less than a mile in, that's when I see the second tower collapse.
So this sounds like a preteen thing maybe you see in the classroom.
Many of these artists have lived the immigrant life, and their hybrid sounds and world-weary raps offer an unsparing view of the African urban landscape.
They also take the glamour out of life as an immigrant, which always includes pressure from back home to send cash from the land of milk and honey.
Somali rapper K'Naan celebrates the Western Union connection on a song called 15 Minutes Away.
(Soundbite of song, ""15 Minutes Away"")
Mr.
K'NAAN (Singer): (Singing) She sent me Western Union so I can make it to him.
It felt so good when she said write this 11 digits.
I go (unintelligible).
I'm desperate, and I need it.
Feels like an angel speaking.
I can hardly believe it.
African Boy, a Nigerian living in London, finds a dubious solution to poverty in his playful celebration of shoplifting.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) (Unintelligible).
These days, singing the pride of African nationalism is old school.
The artists on this CD bring both new musical energy and raw candor to the table.
Senegalese veteran Awadi lays the blame for the 2006 boat exodus squarely on the failures of his countrys leaders.
That is brave.
And this compilation is your ticket to a whole new world of African music-making.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing in foreign language)
Banning Eyre is senior editor at afropop.org.
He reviewed the new compilation ""Yes We Can,"" songs about leaving Africa.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
The latest fundraising numbers for the Democratic presidential race are pretty astonishing.
Barack Obama raised $40 million in March; rival Hillary Clinton raised 20 million.
That's actually down about 15 million from their record-breaking performances in February.
Back then Democrats were typically telling pollsters they'd be happy with either Obama or Clinton as the party's nominee.
That was before the campaign entered its hand-to-hand combat phase.
Recent polling now shows that almost 30 percent of Clinton supporters and nearly 20 percent of Obama's say if their candidate isn't the nominee, they may vote Republican.
More on this from NPR's Ina Jaffe.
Two thousand hardcore Democratic activists gathered in San Jose this past weekend for the state party's annual convention.
It's the last place on earth you'd expect to hear anyone bad-mouthing the party's possible presidential nominees.
But mention Hillary Clinton to Obama supporter Charlotte Pierce and you can hear the disdain in her voice.
I just think that Hillary is upset because she thought she was going to rise to the throne and it's just not happening.
But I am disappointed in what Hillary has done.
She's flung a lot of mud very unnecessarily.
Another Obama supporter, Quinn Gardener, is so turned off, he's thinking the unthinkable.
Oh boy.
You know, honestly, it's a question we'd been talking about a lot today.
Saying if Hillary Clinton got the nomination, would you still vote for her?
I don't know at this point.
I wish I had a better answer.
Not far away, at the Hillary Clinton table, supporter Candace Bashon(ph) gave Barack Obama the most backhanded of compliments.
I think he's a very attractive man, he looks great in a suit.
But I'm more of a policy person, so I was impressed that Hillary would take questions from the crowd, and she knows her stuff.
Bashon was volunteering with Lisa Simon, who said if Obama got the nomination, well, she'd never vote for John McCain.
But she knows other Clinton backers who would.
And they were telling me that they cannot vote for Obama.
They were also telling me that they have real issues with the Reverend Wright's comments.
Controversy over the inflammatory comments of Obama's former pastor has been kept alive not only by some conservative critics but also by the Clinton campaign.
They've acknowledged raising the issue in trying to win over superdelegates.
And Obama supporters were furious when Clinton surrogate James Carville compared New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson to Judas because he endorsed the Illinois senator.
Each side carefully catalogs its wounds.
Hillary Clinton's backers were outraged when Senator Patrick Leahy and others called on her to quit the race.
Some women supporting Clinton blasted Obama for pulling out Clinton's chair for her at a debate, calling it demeaning.
The lists go on and on.
Mr.
BILL KERIK(ph) (Democratic Campaign Consultant): You know, everybody says, oh, this is a really tough campaign.
You know, the truth is by contemporary political standards, so far it hasn't been that bad.
Democratic campaign consultant Bill Kerik says there's another reason why the battle seems so fierce.
On the Democratic side there's this frustration about the Bush years, so we've got to win this election and it's so important to put a Democratic in the White House.
You know, that feeling tends to lead people to overreact to anything they think is potentially damaging.
But with the nomination likely to be decided by the votes of superdelegates, the potential for damage to the party is real, says Democratic analyst Gary South.
Especially, he says, with Obama's African-American supporters.

We do not need to be in a situation where our most reliable voter bloc is alienated and turned off by a situation where it looks to them as if the first black potential nominee of this party has the nomination taken away from him by a bunch of power brokers operating in the back room.

But with nearly three weeks to go before the next vote in Pennsylvania, Democrats have plenty of time to mull over various scenarios of disaster, and supporters of each candidate will continue to measure - and exploit - every perceived offense.
Ina Jaffe, NPR News.
NPR's business news starts with video game giants racing to consolidate.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
I'm dead serious.
I had a racing heartbeat and stuff like that.
So - but I'm OK.
South Africans had gathered last night to celebrate the life of Nelson Mandela, as much as to mourn his death yesterday, at the age of 95.
The passing of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, beloved as an international hero, is also resonating around the globe.
We're going to be covering that throughout this morning.
We begin, though, where his political struggle began - in Johannesburg; joined by New York Times Johannesburg bureau chief Lydia Polgreen.
Good morning.
Good morning.
So the moment has come that South Africa - and actually, many of us - had been bracing for, ever since Mandela took ill last June.
Tell us more about what we were just hearing, South Africans coming together in really both grief and joy.
Yes.
It was extraordinary last night.
I was in front of the home where Mandela lived for many years.
It was actually an unseasonably chilly morning.
Everyone just wanted to joyfully praise the name of Nelson Mandela.
So there was a lot of, you know, ""Viva, Mandela!"" and singing the old songs of the struggle, the struggle that he helped win.
So it was a joyful moment, tinged around the edges with sadness; but also the knowledge that he lived a long and good life, and that he's gone on to his reward.
Remind us of what he meant to his nation because this experience of his death, so different from the passing - I think, really, you can say - of other former heads of states.
That's right.
I mean, I think that when people called Nelson Mandela the ""Father of the Nation,"" that's not an exaggeration.
He was really the central figure who created a country out of the ruins of a horrific and brutal racial segregation system called apartheid.

And when he came out of prison without any bitterness in his heart, and negotiated an end to that system of racial rule that embraced all South Africans regardless of race, he really created something that the world has not seen.
And so I think there's a feeling of loss that the person who personified that ideal has passed.
What about for the rest of Africa - because you have traveled and reported on the continent elsewhere.
That's right.
For the rest of Africa, Nelson Mandela remains the gold standard of leadership.
I mean, remember, we're talking about a continent where many presidents have clung onto power long past their sell-by date.
You look just in neighboring Zimbabwe; Robert Mugabe has been in power for more than 30 years.

So the powerful example that Nelson Mandela set by stepping down after a single term as president and handing over to a democratic process that has continued - essentially - flawlessly since then, is something that people all over Africa point to and aspire to.
The funeral is planned.
What can we expect?
You'd have to go back to the funeral of Winston Churchill to imagine an event of such global importance and significance.

Nelson Mandela is universally beloved, so you're going to see pretty much every leader in the world - every living United States president; you know, a huge delegation from Congress; and then multiply that by every country in the world.
But then on top of that, you'll also have ordinary South Africans from across the country.
One can't help but think back to that day in 1994, when South Africans lined up in their millions to cast their votes for Nelson Mandela.
So it's a fitting bookend to his life, that they would line up once again to pay their final respects to him.
